articles.headline: U.K. Economy Falters as Brexit Looms. Amsterdam Sees Risks, and Opportunity.
articles.snippet: New data for 2018’s fourth quarter shows the British economy growing at its slowest pace since 2012, bringing the broad impact of a no-deal split from the European Union into sharp relief.
articles.abstract: New data for 2018’s fourth quarter shows the British economy growing at its slowest pace since 2012, bringing the broad impact of a no-deal split from the European Union into sharp relief.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — If anyone in the Netherlands is happy about Britain jilting the European Union, they keep that sentiment to themselves. The country has been built on trade, with huge volumes of goods flowing from its ports across the English Channel. Brexit, as the divorce is known, has proved disruptive.

articles.headline: ‘A Woman, Just Not That Woman’: How Sexism Plays Out on the Trail
articles.snippet: Critics called Hillary Clinton “shrill” and “unlikable.” It’s no coincidence that the same words are being used against Elizabeth Warren, Kirsten Gillibrand and Kamala Harris.
articles.abstract: Critics called Hillary Clinton “shrill” and “unlikable.” It’s no coincidence that the same words are being used against Elizabeth Warren, Kirsten Gillibrand and Kamala Harris.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the words of her detractors during the 2016 presidential race, Hillary Clinton was abrasive and shrill. She was aloof. She was unlikable.

articles.headline: With Shutdown Looming, Border Deal Is Reached ‘in Principle’
articles.snippet: Lawmakers said they had reached the agreement after an impasse over the number of ICE detention beds had threatened to derail negotiations.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers said they had reached the agreement after an impasse over the number of ICE detention beds had threatened to derail negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House and Senate negotiators on Monday night agreed in principle to provide $1.375 billion for fencing and other physical barriers at the Mexican border, part of a broader agreement that would stave off another partial government shutdown without funding President Trump’s wall.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Washington Post Finds Itself in the Middle of the Jeff Bezos Story
articles.snippet: The paper, which has flourished under Mr. Bezos’ ownership, is now reporting on his dispute with another publisher, American Media Inc.
articles.abstract: The paper, which has flourished under Mr. Bezos’ ownership, is now reporting on his dispute with another publisher, American Media Inc.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos says owning The Washington Post is a “complexifier” for him. The newspaper could say the same about him.

articles.headline: Latest Warning Sign for Markets: A Possible ‘Earnings Recession’
articles.snippet: Wall Street analysts expect profits for S&P 500 companies to decline 1.7 percent this quarter, a reversal from a forecast of a 3.3 percent increase.
articles.abstract: Wall Street analysts expect profits for S&P 500 companies to decline 1.7 percent this quarter, a reversal from a forecast of a 3.3 percent increase.
articles.lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

articles.headline: In China, This Video Game Lets You Be a Tiger Mom or a Driven Dad
articles.snippet: Mete out love and discipline. Set ambitious goals. Endure a teenager’s first dates. Fans say the game Chinese Parents is a surprisingly poignant exercise in role reversal.
articles.abstract: Mete out love and discipline. Set ambitious goals. Endure a teenager’s first dates. Fans say the game Chinese Parents is a surprisingly poignant exercise in role reversal.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — You want your children to do well in school. You want them to have nice friends and interesting hobbies and to not go out with creeps. You may even want them to be happy.
articles.byline: By Carolyn Zhang and Raymond Zhong

articles.headline: Turkey’s Mass Trials Deepen Wounds Left by Attempted Coup
articles.snippet: While the sweeping verdicts are welcomed by the government and its supporters, critics say they are deeply flawed and represent collective punishment.
articles.abstract: While the sweeping verdicts are welcomed by the government and its supporters, critics say they are deeply flawed and represent collective punishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: SILIVRI, Turkey — Turkish courts are just weeks from concluding some 300 mass trials intended to draw a line under the most traumatic event of Turkey’s recent history: the failed 2016 coup that killed 251 people, mostly civilians, and wounded more than 2,000.
